text:
I'll go ahead and get started. So this is an embryo
going under morphogenesis.

So it's basically
changing shape in-- this is obviously
sped up but it's

a rather incredible process,
which I didn't really know about or hadn't looked closely
at until this project.

And this is another
3D version of this. And I think the
coolest part to me

is looking at all the cells
moving around as this thing goes from a sphere into--

I think this is turning
into a little fish or maybe a little salamander. It has a little legs
going on there too.

So this process is
pretty incredible, right? I think we can agree on that.

And the thing we
wanted to ask is, what would happen if we could
do a synthetic variant of this?

And so the question is,
well, how do you actually make that into a real robot? So can you do something
like this in a real robot?

And what's the basic mechanism? So we want to ask,
what is going on

to enable this type
of shape change, this kind of melting behavior? If we look at an
animation of cells

as they're undergoing this
process of morphogenesis, and if we look closely at
them, this is the key behavior.

If you notice it-- and I'll
play this again in a minute-- but the cells are actually
changing rearranging order,

right? So their topology is changing. And so cells can move with
respect to one another. And by moving with
respect to each other,

you can change the
overall shape of. So this is what we kind
of identified the key

in both the biology,
and actually, these Hollywood interpretations
of it is rearrangement.

So if you can
rearrange your cells, you can do some
interesting things. And more specifically,
your rearranging in tight

packed situations. So it's not like quadrotors
flying in formation. We're looking at things
that are tight packed.

And so they're making
a cohesive material. And then it's not--

another key to it
is it's happening throughout the material, right? It's not just around the
surface or something like this.

And so this is kind of what we
identified as our target, was, can we do this
rearrangement tight packed

and throughout the collective? And that's what today's talk
is going to be mostly about. And it's always
good to look at what

other people have done so far. So people have done
collective robots before that they can
change shape, that

have units and can move around. So we'll just look
at a couple of them. So this is from Mark Yim,
his modular robot system.

So they can drive around. They can connect to each other. And they can disconnect and
change shape of this system.

But you notice that any
motion of one of these things requires it to basically
disconnect and drive around.

And so you get motion around
the surface of the thing, right around the perimeter
is how they can change.

This is a recent paper
in science robotics. Yeager, and actually, Spinco
was on this paper, yeah,

yeah, Mark's former postdoc. Yeah. But similar thing
where again, they're

able to move around
the perimeter. And so we get rearrangement. We're not be able
to do it throughout.

And then this is one that
probably people have seen. This is Kilobots, which I feel
sorry for the grad students who

were involved in this project. 1,000 robots, a lot
of robots to make.

But again, we see
this same behavior where we can do really
cool shape change, but it's limited to
perimeter motions, right.

So we're not actually moving
anything in the bulk of it. So this is kind of
what we looking at

to talk about today
is what I'm claiming is that this is
kind of a key step

to realize these kind of
programmable matter things that we see in tissue
or science fiction is,

to do what people have
done with rearrangements, but actually do them in
a tight-packed situation where we're getting motion
throughout the material.

And it turns out, no one's
done it because it's hard. It's much easier to
drive around the outside than it is to
rearrange things that

are tightly packed together. So a little outline for how
I'm going to break this down.

We'll talk about the
design of the robots first. So what did we learn
from the embryo?

And then how do we
implement it into a robot? Once we built the robot,
learning about how it behaved,

this was pretty interesting. Once you do multi-robot things,
unlike when you have one robot

and you program it, and it
basically does, hopefully, what you tell it to do. When we have multi-robots, you
tell each one to do something.

And then you put
them all together. And something happens, right? And so that's been very fun. It's a little more
like biology where

you observe as you change
different parameters, what happens to the collective. And then finally, I'll end
with some demos of things

our collective can do,
which, just as a warning, is not going to be Terminator.

So keep your expectations low. And then I want to
recognize the team here.

So Matt Devlin is my PhD student
who has put in a ton of work into this.

So he's the main driving
force in all of this. Otger Campus is the
mechano biologist

who's been helping us
to understand the cells and how they work and all the
forces and everything going on.

And then this was
his postdoc, Sangwoo, who's now a professor at EPFL.

So it's a international team. So it's always challenging to
find times when we can all meet.

But let's start with the design. So this our goal here. This is a rearrangement in
tight packed and throughout.

And the question is, how do we
do that in a robotic system? And we're going to start with
first just this rearrangement

piece. So if we look more closely
at that simulation of how the cells are interacting
with each other,

let's zoom into four of those
and watch how they move. So you've got two cells
here and two cells here.

And the most basic way we
could rearrange or a basic way we can rearrange the
topology of this,

so basically, these
are neighbors. And these are not neighbors. And we're going to change it
so that these come together,

and those split apart. So you can watch that happen. And that's called the T1
transition in biology,

or in topology, more generally. So this is very basic
transition where one and four come together,
two and three split apart.

It is also known
as intercalation, because basically,
these cells here are intercalating like this.

And we are essentially
going to elongate the tissue along this axis as we get
the things coming together

like that. So this basic functionality
that underpins

a lot of biological shape
change and strength change. And so, OK, so we've
identified this T1.

And so then, how do we
recreate it in robots? And so there's three
different things

I'm going to talk about
for recreating this T1. And first, we're
going to look at, how do we actually apply the
forces necessary to create

T1 transition? So the first thing we
noticed was that we've

got one and four here. And somehow, there
must be some force that pulls one towards four,
because they're apart,

and then they come together. So we said, OK, let's
look at ways to do that. And I'm going to show
all the-- not all,

some of the very bad
ideas we had because I think that's fun to show. When often you go to a talk, and
you just see the final product,

and you say, wow, how
did they come with that? But there's lots of things like
this that didn't work first. So these were all a bunch
of little cells we made.

And the idea was, we would have,
on each cell, these little arms

that would reach out. And then they would pull. And they would
reciprocate like this to try to pull the
other cells towards it.

So I will play that kind
of working, but not really.

So it just kind of
wiggles back and forth, and we don't really
get any net motion. So this is something
like four years ago.

And I'll just stop
it there because it does about the same thing. The next thing we
thought of is, OK,

well, what if we attach
the two cells that we care about with some kind of--

here, I think there
badger tractors, but some active
attention mechanism that would pull the two
cells together so you could--

they would split
apart like this. You could put them together. And then if you pull hard
enough in that cable,

you can pull two and two
together and split one and one apart. This is great, but you can
only do one motion, right?

You're kind of stuck. And after you do
your one motion, you could pull
one back together. But you can't really do random,
arbitrary rearrangements

in your system. So that wasn't a
great idea either. So we looked a little
more at what's going on

as you do this intercalation. And so this is a
similar drawing. But now, we have A
and C coming together

as B and D are splitting apart. And we read some old papers that
were explaining how some of this

worked. And partly, it's due
to this flow of lipids

in the membrane of the cells. So there's actually
this recirculation of the membrane that goes
this way and then comes in.

And if any of you have
done vine robot things, you start thinking, well,
that looks a lot like a water wiggly or a vine robot.

So I started thinking, oh,
all my projects are actually going to be the same. And we tried this. And it didn't work.

So I'll spare you. This is not a vine
robot product talk. So we looked at it again.

And if you look really
close right in here, we said, OK, so A and
C are coming together.

B and D are coming apart. What are the forces
or the flows that are happening at that junction?

And so basically, you're
getting, on C, for instance, you're seeing C is
kind of coming in.

Whereas, D and B the
membrane is going away. And the same with A.
A is kind of coming

in like this because if you look
at right here, there's more--

it's hard to see. But as you go from this
picture to that picture, there is more membrane
here than there is here.

So there's a net flow in. And there's a net
flow out on B and D. We said, OK, so how
do we replicate this?

So we started thinking,
well, maybe it's about surface flows
or tangential forces

acting along the surface
that can essentially make a flow of material
right along the surface.

So here, we've got
a rubber band driven by a motor along some
pulleys on the outside

to essentially get
a flow of material around the outside of the robot. So this is an early version.

And you can kind of see
things moving around. You can see the belts moving. And it was kind of
working and then

the white smoke of not goodness. So this didn't really
work in the end.

The belts were a little bit
of a hassle to work with and they had their own problems,
which I won't go into now.

But we started realizing,
well, maybe we can just drive gears along the surface.

And so the gear could
actually be essentially like, if you think, well,
the gear in the inside

is not doing anything. On the outside, it's essentially
creating this tangential force or a shear flow.

So this is an early
version of this. And this is driven by one motor. And they're all moving together.

Now, which direction
do they need to move? It's a little bit tricky
because you need them basically

running in opposite
directions to create these convergent flows. So this one will be coming in. And this one will be coming in
this way, which kind of pulls

a flow this way. On this side, there's
a divergent flow. So you have two convergent
flows, two divergent flows.

I'll play that again. So there's a convergent
flow at the bottom and a divergent
flow on the outside.

And so when you start
putting these together, you get these flows
starting to work together.

The four kind of worked. But you can see, there's
some big dead zones in there. And so it works better
actually with eight.

And at eight, you can keep
going with this, right? You could have a
million of these. And you would essentially have
perfect control on the surface.

It turns out eight is enough
to approximate surface flows of a cell.

And so this is just showing
how we can control them all to move around. And at this point, we
decided to just give everyone

its own motor. And that allowed
us just a lot more control than trying to do
a somewhat complex linkage

in there or a gear train. Also has the advantage of
you can hot-swap things in and out when
they break, which

is helpful when you're
building a lot of robots. And so that was
essentially the design that we stuck with in the end.

We moved the gears a
little bit further back so that they're barely going out
past this edge of the robot.

And that allows us to get
this basic tangential force along the surface. And then we made it blue and
gold for Santa Barbara colors.

And that was what we did
for the forces, right? So that was the first
main design challenge.

The second part for to create
T1 transition is adhesion. The cells need to
stick together.

That's pretty
straightforward-- magnets. Many people use magnets
for these, right?

So there's just
this video again, where you see the cells are
essentially stuck together. Magnets are a very
convenient way to do this.

So we did that as well. We thought a little
bit about how to design our magnets
in that if you start

with this red curve, which is
just magnets kind of embedded in the robot, and
let's say we need

some force of about
12 newtons or so, if you look at just putting
a big magnet inside,

you have this curve. But if we don't want
the force to be too far, once they've come
apart, because you

want to be able to
rearrange somewhat easily. And so if instead, you use a
smaller magnet, you can cheat.

But you put it right
at the surface. So you actually get that
initial contact touching. You can get the same force.

But you can get a
quicker decay because you have a smaller magnet closer.

So we chose that medium
magnet for our magnets. And then we want any two
robots to touch another robot

and connect. And so the magnets are
not glued in place. They're floating in
this little holder.

And so the magnets can just
rotate around to any orientation they need to match with
the nearest neighbor.

And then the third part
for the design of the robot was trying to polarize them.

So in the sense that if
I'm trying to tell a tissue to elongate in a
certain direction,

it needs to know what
that direction is. And all the cells need
to know that direction. So if we have this
example again,

A and C need to know that
they're supposed to go this way. And B and D needs
to know they're going to go this
way for the thing

to elongate in that direction. So we need to communicate
with our cells in some way.

So one of our first ideas
was a really bright light on one end of the arena.

And then we would
have some photodiodes. You can see them hanging off the
end of the circuit boards here.
And I'll just play that. I mean, it sort of works. There's kind of a downside.

You can see it is that
you get shadowing, right? So it worked great for
the first two ones. But then this one's getting
shadowed by the other ones.

And so that wasn't
the best solution. We then went to this
idea where the lights
are above and swiping across.

So instead of a
spatial control, this is more of a temporal control
as when it went across, you would look at your sensors.

And if it got lit
here before there, then you know which
direction was the direction you wanted to go in.

So this was kind of OK. But it kind of made
us feel like we're going to get sick or something.

So this wasn't
the best solution. It had some problems
in implementation. So then we thought about,
well, what if we just

use polarized light? Because you can polarize
light and essentially give a direction to it.

And so this is a demo of that. So what we've done here is
this is the circuit board.

And then it has
eight photodiodes. You can see them,
the little squares. And then on top of each of
those is a polarized film.

And they're each
oriented radially, so pointing in
towards the center. And now you're looking through a
second polarized film right now.

The camera has a second
polarized film on it, which is what the light
is also shining through. And so as I rotate
this device, you

can see that black is
always here, right? No matter the orientation
of the device, black

is always on the side
because it's at that point that it's cross polarized
and it gets dark.

And so by doing this, no
matter the orientation of the physical
robot, I can always

have it know which way is North
or whatever you want to call it. So then I can just have a bunch
of robots randomly aligned,

throw them in an arena that it's
lit by this polarized light, and they always know
which way is which.

So we put it all together. And this is our
beautiful little robots. So this is a little
custom circuit board

on top, a bunch of these
little cheapest motors we could find on Amazon here.

There's the batteries,
the gears, and a couple of them touching together. And here's the sensors
you can see there.

And so then the question
is, can we do T1 transition with all that stuff? And so that's what
this looks like.

So here's four of them set up
in that initial configuration. We shine the light,
polarize this way.

It goes that way. We put them back to neutral. Then we put it this way. And then they can
go up that way. So we have a nice control
over this with four cells

to be able to do the T1
transition pretty robustly.

And you can also note, it's
kind of cool to see here, these cells were not placed
in any particular orientation, right?

This one has the
blue board this way. This one has it this way. This one has it this way. So you can just
throw them in there.

And then once you flash
the light on them, they change the drive
pattern of their gears

to essentially all become
oriented in the same direction. So they're not physically
oriented the same way.

But they can just
reorient their gears. And then they're functionally
oriented in the same direction.

Cool, so that's the
design of the robots. So that's what they look like. That's how we came
to the design. And then the next question is,
what controls those motions,

right? So when we want to
have these transitions, how do we control it? And what are the
parameters that control it?

So we did our T1 transition. And then we're
looking at parameters. And we're going to
start with shape change.

So the two things that we're
interested in generally are shape change-- so controlling the general
shape of it-- but then also,

strength change, so kind of like
the melting of the Terminator, when you apply some load
to it, can you soften it.

And so these are the parameters
that we looked at for, how does the robot change?

Or how can we change the
shape or the strength of the collective? And so this is the signal that
we're sending to the gears.

And so each motor
gets a signal that has some average
intensity or force.

And then we have
some fluctuations around that average force. And this is something we
find in cells that they

fluctuate their forces. They don't just give a
constant tension to them. And so one thing we
were curious about

is, well, what's the effect
of these fluctuations? And maybe we could
learn a little something about why it's helpful to
fluctuate as opposed to just

drive with a constant force. So those are two parameters
we're going to change. And so these are the
first set of tests.

This is just with
that interpolation. So it's just the four
cells doing this motion.

And so the first test
is we just vary-- this is the average force. So you vary the average force.

And as you increase it
slowly, you basically get no motion, no
motion, no motion. Then you get to this threshold,
and then all of a sudden,

you're going to move. And then beyond
that, you basically always move if you have
an intensity high enough.

So that's what's changing
the average force. And then you see a
similar thing when you change the
average fluctuation,

so the fluctuation amplitude. So you hold some force. And if you're not fluctuating at
all, you actually get no motion.

And then as you get more
and more fluctuation, eventually, you get
the same threshold. So you're going to go from no
motion to this full motion,

crossing a pretty steep
threshold like this. All right, so now, this is where
it becomes interactive to make

sure you're still awake. If we have these
two plots, so this

is what happens as I vary
F, the average force. This is what happens as I vary
the amplitude of fluctuation.

Now, let's say I vary
those two things together. So now this is 2D
phase portrait.

Or yeah, yeah, OK, so let's

Yeah, the dark. Dark on here. And what about that corner? Probably light.

Probably light, OK. And then how is the

be something that's

going to be more of a
step, based on the fact

that these two are
sharp thresholds? [INAUDIBLE] What's that?

The square's, like
a small square? And then it becomes blue.

Yeah, so blue, and

because both of these,

as you're ampling, you're

That's interesting. So you think there's

Correct, quadrant right. Yeah. That's blue. OK. It's pretty close.

So essentially, we get almost
split, all white in the top,

all blue here. What happens here,
up for debate.

these as slices of this plot.

So as I go across

And that's essentially
one of these plots, which is flat and kicks up like this. So we get this pretty distinct--

well, as you fluctuate more, you

But we don't want to make any

Do you think it's mostly

Like, you need to almost

So this is why if you put

But you need to get over

Then by fluctuate
thing about this, I'm going to get

And so then, which, anyone

that are about 25 pounds
plate on top of them. But they're very

so they have some strength--
can we change that strength? Can we fluidize and

by controlling these parameters? And so we can turn

well, it's just a picture. That's such a good

Oh, there they go. So we can turn them on. We can soften the thing. And we can drop the weight.

So we want to look at what

basically their material

properties of just an off trio. And we just squashed

brittle, up to about 140 newtons

on our one little tripod,
and then they yield.

And then they get into this
kind of intermediate state here, as you can see there. And then they collapse fully.

So that's what they look like,
just off, so uncontrolled.

And then now we can
do the same thing. We can start controlling them
by varying this inter unit

force between the gears. And we can soften
it a huge amount.

So this it's normalized
to its max force there. And then we can see how
it falls off this way.

And similarly, we can
do with the vibrations. And so we can drop
the stiffness way down with vibrations as well.

So with these two control knobs,
we're able to both change shape, but also change the
strength of the collective.

And we can make one of these
